biospec_descr.textblock: Peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBLs); Plasma; Tumor Tissue

brief_summary.textblock:
This primary purpose of this study is to obtain blood samples from participants with both
      early and later stages of melanoma (Stage II/III and Stage IV). The researchers hope to
      better understand an abnormal protein found in many melanoma tumors called the BRAFV600
      mutation.

      There will be two separate cohorts (groups) of participants on this study. You will be
      placed in one of the Groups.

      Group 1-For participants with advanced melanoma: Your existing tumor tissue sample will be
      compared to the blood samples given in order to further analyze and to understand the
      BRAFV600E gene mutation.

      Group 2-For participants with stage II/III melanoma: Following surgery, blood samples will
      be collected and analyzed.

      Understanding the BRAFV600E gene mutation in melanoma will help the researchers better
      understand the disease, and help plan treatment options for people with melanoma of all
      stages in the future.

clinical_study.brief_title: Utility of Novel BRAF Test for Melanoma

detailed_description.textblock:
There will be no extra clinic visits for this study. These research blood samples will be
      drawn at the same time as your regularly scheduled blood draws that are part of standard
      care for melanoma.

      About 2 to 4 teaspoons of blood will be drawn for each research sample.

      Depending on which group you are in, you will have either a one time blood draw or ongoing
      blood work for 1-2 years.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Biopsy proven advanced (unresectable stage IIIC or stage IV)or high risk (stage II or
             stage III) malignant melanoma

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  History of a different malignancy except for the following circumstances:
             disease-free for at least 2 years and deemed by the investigator to be at low risk
             for recurrence; or non-metastatic prostate cancer, cervical cancer in situ and basal
             cell or squamous cell carcinoma

          -  Known history of a different BRAF mutant malignancy

study_pop.textblock:
Patients being treated at Massachusetts General Hospital, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and
        Beth Isreal Deaconess Medical Center

clinical_study.official_title: Exploring the Utility of a Novel BRAF Test in Patients With Melanoma

primary_outcome.description: To determine the specificity and sensitivity of the blood based assay vis-a-vis tissue based BRAF analysis in patients with advanced and high-risk melanoma
primary_outcome.measure: Determine Specificity and Sensitivity of Blood Based Assay

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: To explore the pharmacodynamic effects of MAPK pathway inhibitors (including selective BRAF inhibitors, MEK inhibitors, and ERK inhibitors) utilizing pre-and on-treatment peripheral blood BRAFV600E mutational testing in patients with advanced melanoma, (non-resectable Stage III or Stage IV)
secondary_outcome.measure: Explore Pharmacodynamic Effects of MAPK Pathway Inhibitors

secondary_outcome.description: To define the prognostic value of peripheral blood BRAFV600 mutational testing in patients with Stage II and resectable Stage III melanoma
secondary_outcome.measure: Define Prognostic Value of Peripheral Blood BRAFV600 Testing in Melanoma

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective
